Explanations about Options.--namespace(M):
Select a different name space. The name spaces file (file names, the default), udp
 (local UDP ports), and tcp (local TCP ports) are supported. For ports, either the
 port number or the symbolic name can be specified. If there is no ambiguity, the
 shortcut notation name/space (e.g., 80/tcp) can be used.
Explanations about Options.-v(C): On the command line, you may also want to execute "fuser -v <port>/<proto>" first, to see what you are going to kill.

Explanations about Options.-l(M): Show only listening sockets. (These are omitted by default.)
Explanations about Options.-n(M): Show numerical addresses instead of trying to determine symbolic host, port or user names.
Explanations about Options.-p(M): Show the PID and name of the program to which each socket belongs.

Explanations about Options.-l(M):
Listen for an incoming connection rather than initiating a connection to a remote
 host. The destination and port to listen on can be specified either as non-optional
 arguments, or with options -s and -p respectively. Cannot be used together with -x
 or -z. Additionally, any timeouts specified with the -w option are ignored.

ul_246903: # Start a process (nc) that listens on port 8080
$ nc -l 8080 & bg
[1] 17454
[1] nc -l 8080

# Get the process listening on port 8080:
$ fstat | grep :8080
cmihai   nc         17454    3* internet stream tcp 0x0 *:8080

$ kill $(portpid 8080)
[1] + Terminated           nc -l 8080

Explanations about Options.-A(C): You could try "nmap -v -A -p {the port that you can't recognise} {the host IP}".
Explanations about Options.-n(M): Tells Nmap to never do reverse DNS
Explanations about Options.-v(M):
(Increase verbosity level) , -vlevel (Set verbosity level)
 Increases the verbosity level, causing Nmap to print more information about the scan
 in progress. Open ports are shown as they are found and completion time estimates are
 provided when Nmap thinks a scan will take more than a few minutes. Use it twice or
 more for even greater verbosity: -vv, or give a verbosity level directly, for example
 -v3.
